assets.headline: Political Leaders Gather to Pay Tribute to Lautenberg
assets.original_headline: Political Leaders Gather to Pay Tribute to Lautenberg
assets.summary: A host of dignitaries will eulogize Frank R. Lautenberg, a five-term United States senator, at a funeral service Wednesday in Manhattan.
assets.original_summary: A host of dignitaries will eulogize Frank R. Lautenberg, a five-term United States senator, at a funeral service Wednesday in Manhattan.

images.name: 06LAUTENBERGweb
images.caption: The coffin bearing Senator Frank R. Lautenberg arrived on Wednesday morning at  the Park Avenue Synagogue. Mr. Lautenberg died  Monday at age 89.

assets.headline: Christie Decides on October Vote for New Senator
assets.original_headline: Christie Decides on October Vote for New Senator
assets.byline: By KATE ZERNIKE and DAVID M. HALBFINGER
assets.summary: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey’s announcement of an unusual special election was immediately criticized for costing the state $24 million and for setting up a schedule that was likely to confuse the voting public.
assets.original_summary: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey’s announcement of an unusual special election was immediately criticized for costing the state $24 million and for setting up a schedule that was likely to confuse the voting public.

images.name: jpNJSENATE
images.caption: Gov. Chris Christie at a news conference in Trenton on Tuesday. He denies there were political calculations behind his decision.

assets.headline: Special Election Timing in New Jersey Points to a Weak G.O.P. Field
assets.original_headline: Special Election Timing in New Jersey Points to a Weak G.O.P. Field
assets.summary: Gov. Chris Christie’s decision to schedule a special election for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg’s seat on Oct. 16 suggests that he evaluated the potential Republican challengers and did not like what he saw.

assets.headline: Too Old to Judge? Albany  Reconsiders

images.summary: A bill in New York State would extend the retirement age to 80 for hundreds of judges, including the chief judge of the Court of Appeals, Jonathan Lippman, above.

assets.headline: Clarinet, With Cicada Chorus
assets.original_headline: Clarinet, With Cicada Chorus
assets.summary: As billions of cicadas enter the brief, noisy mating stage of their 17-year life cycle, David Rothenberg performs with some of the insects to show how animals use musical sounds to communicate.

assets.headline: A Century of Cicadas
assets.original_headline: A Century of Cicadas
assets.summary: Periodical cicadas live underground for 17 or 13 years before emerging to sing, mate and die. This year’s cicadas are Brood II, one of 15 surviving regional broods.

assets.headline: Through a New Lens

assets.headline: ‘People Think It’s Over’
assets.original_headline: ‘People Think It’s Over’
assets.summary: Drugs may have prevented people with H.I.V. from dying of AIDS, but even as they reach the once-unthinkable age of 50, their lives continue to be ravaged by the virus.
assets.original_summary: Drugs may have prevented people with H.I.V. from dying of AIDS, but even as they reach the once-unthinkable age of 50, their lives continue to be ravaged by the virus.

images.name: 02HIV1_SPAN
images.caption: In his Midtown apartment, Steve Schalchlin, 59, has a piano that he plays every day. He said his music has kept him alive.
images.headline: Spared Death, but Struggling to Live
images.summary: Drugs may have prevented people with H.I.V. from dying, but their lives continue to be ravaged by illness. Steve Schalchlin, above, said music has kept him alive.

assets.body:
The Times Close Up

Sam Roberts hosts an inside look at the most compelling articles in Sunday's Times, 10 p.m. on Saturdays and 10 a.m. on Sundays, on NY1 News. This weekend's guests include The Times’s Bill Keller, Ben Brantley and Patrick Healy, as well as Diane Paulus, Jerry Mitchell, Mark Brokaw, Harold Holzer, David Margolick.
